name: Natural Selection
description:
The goal of the deck is to threaten the corporation with a very diverse set of breakers. The infamous Datasucker-Parasite combo deals with low strength ice like Komainu. Clone Chip enables this combo to be used mid run as Quetzal's green hair fails to hide her inner wish to become a Shaper.

Why The Personal Touch? To enable Yog.0 to bypass Lotus Field, Viper and to slip out of the otherwise deadly Chum-Kitsune-combo.

Does this deck have any weaknesses? The most apparent one would be Toolbooth, which really is a weakness to every runner deck. To combat Toolboth, I suggest using Knight (Which was added just so you would be able to deal with that nasty piece of economical concrete), Datasucker+Parasite or just pray and run somewhere else.

Another weakness (Which all Anarchs share) is card draw. Wyldside helps you out somewhat, but I usually never experience a problem with this.

Here follows a quick ruthrough of how I use this deck to deal with the different corp-decks in my playgroup:

NBN:FA: Natural Selection fares pretty well here, thanks to Quetzals build in answer to wraparound. They need to take more care early game and will have to work harder to get that Astro-engine running. Medium is wonderful against FA, as their uninteractive playstyle makes for some easy R&D-running. Remember, a NBN-player who has to spend a turn Virus Purging is a sad NBN-player.

Weyland-Glacier: Laugh at their Hadrian's Walls and Ice Walls. Cry when they ress Toolbooth. Don't be afraid of early runs. Especially on R&D. Watch out for the Crisium Grid+Off The Grid-combo. Usually one of the easier matchups.

Weyland Tag 'n Bag: Plascrete Carapace. Run early and often. Get an Imp out to thrash any Scorched you come across. Usually works out in your favour.

NBN Tagstorm: As NBN does not have very heavy ICE (Except for Toolboth). Wraparound won't save them. Same as with Weyland Tag 'n Bag. Try to get the Plascrete Carapace and run early.

HB Glacier: Usually a little tricker than the Weyland version. Their deck is very economy-reliant. Use Imp to thrash their sex-bots. Don't be afraid to make bad runs to make the corp ress ICE.

Jinteki PE: Mimic, Parasite+Datasucker. Mimic works wonders against PE. Together with a The Personal Touch+Yog.0 you will only have to worry about access-traps. Remember to never run last-click and to always have at least 3 cards in your hand when you run. Remember House of Knives and avoid using multi-access and you'll be fine. One more thing to note is to have credits ready to pay for Fetal AI and NAPD.

Jinteki RP: Natural Selection usually works great against RP, as Yog.0 as well as Datasucker+Parasite disables many of their tricks. Thrash, maim, burn and leave your business card.

name: Near-Earth Hub (10/10/14)
SlySquid's Pawnshop v3.3
description: So I've been getting a lot more games in with this deck and have made a few more tweaks to make it more consistent, first being I'm only using Crypsis as my main breaker, it's the every-breaker and will do most of the heavy lifting. Next was switching out Armitage Codebusting for Liberated Account this will net me one less credit but it also needs half the click investment, and if I'm running Crypsis and Wyldside I need all the clicks I can get... Lastly I dropped the Djinn's for more copy's of the cards I was planning on tutoring, the card works on paper but than again, so does communism. It also gave me a few more mills if I have to switch it up and start milling for the win instead of just being aggressive and pressuring every server like I'm intending for this deck to do...

name: SlySquids Bad Pub Control v1.1
description:
This is a deck im excited to make when O&C comes out, also it runs the ID that makes the corp start with a bad pub, not EKim..

Its loosely based off of the Iain Stirling: Retired Spook deck that went something like 25/0 in a FFG company tournament...

name: Cash Money Murder
description: Get money and then murder.

name: Andy (10/10/14)
SlySquid's Pawnshop v3.2
description: So I've been getting a lot more games in with this deck and have made a few more tweaks to make it more consistent, first being I'm only using Crypsis as my main breaker, it's the every-breaker and will do most of the heavy lifting. Next was switching out Armitage Codebusting for Liberated Account this will net me one less credit but it also needs half the click investment, and if I'm running Crypsis and Wyldside I need all the clicks I can get... Lastly I dropped the Djinn's for more copy's of the cards I was planning on tutoring, the card works on paper but than again, so does communism. It also gave me a few more mills if I have to switch it up and start milling for the win instead of just being aggressive and pressuring every server like I'm intending for this deck to do...

name: MILL TILL YOU WENT CRAZY
description:
hello everyone, this is my first fun deck made on netrunnerdb I am not a native speaker , please forgive my poor English expression. I joined netrunner 2months ago, and I was playing magic the gathering. In MTG, there are many ways to deck someone. (Mill deck) I really enjoyed playing a game with surprise to crush my opponent. I usually hate to win through a normal way, not just in ANR, but also in other BGs.There are already a huge amounts of flatlining deck already, however, flatlining someone is not the deck I am looking for.Flatlining someone is really fun, but in a trapping way. I like to control my rival instead of playing mind game.

So I invented this deck=> andromeda: mill till you went crazy.

The major concept is quite simple. 0. Saving money by KT 1. Set your rig with fall guys ,DLRs ,same old things and joshuaB (optional) 2. Having enough breakers ( normally ZU, corroder and alias) 3. Play your account siphon and recur it , making your opponent bankrupt.

=====> Mill

If corp has 0c ,it takes a whole turn to discard one resource! So if you have 3 (fall guys+DLRs) you can mill at least 3 turn = 15 cards (if Joshua is available) 15 cards+ 5 starting hand+ 15mandatory draw+ 10 manual draw(on average)=45 The corp will have less than 10 cards left, it is almost decking!(include Jackson Howard usage)

However,It's clear that its strategies need many cards to deal with. So special order and hostage are all for tutoring the right card. Keyhole is more like a misleading that force the corp to Rez the ice in front of R&D The source + fall Guy is incredibly cool! Don't hesitate to use your fall guy to protect your the source!LOGOs is incredible too. You can tutor your fall guy and account siphon for free! Card explanation:

account siphon

to make the corp go bankrupt, there is no need to actually soak up his money!(If he already used up his money to Rez the ices, that's fine.

calling in favors

A strong midgame Econ with more than 6 or 7 connections.

dirty laundry

Also, use it to force the corp to Rez the ice that you "cannot" actually pass! Be aware of the sentry ice first! The core concept in this deck is to make the corp extremely poor.

hostage

In the very beginning, if your opponent is playing fast advance, pull the source first! If not , pull kati jones to accumulate your Econ

special order

Just a useful tutor.

sure gamble

Omitted.

logos

Very stressful console. If have the source and logos at the same time, that is way more than stress. In the early game you can pull out breakers or MR li to accomplish your combos.

plascrete carapace

Omitted.

data dealer

Trust me, this is extremely strong, In a non-scoring deck. In my experience, the corp will score at least 5AP before I Finish my work. But you may also try to threat the corp to make sure that he is not going to win. In the process, you may get some extra agenda that is totally useless. So data dealer can be a great late game burn.

data leak reversal

Omitted.

fall guy

Use it to protect DLR or the source.

john masanori

To get cards during late game agenda checking in archives, or account siphoning.

joshuaB

Mill 5 cards in a turn!!!

kati jones

Useful Econ.

mr li

Useful drawing for combo pieces.

faerie

We need to show our respect to the corp that we will still attack your remote. With alias only on the rig will make the corp to make careless decision（with archer on scoring server and start to advance agendas）

keyhole

scaring the corp with keyhole is extremely fun!! Against:

CI

simply sipohn the HQ in later game。easy to win since he will draw extremely a lot!

PE

Little ice protected. And siphon will be quite easy to deal with. House of knife strategy is great for Logos because you can take extra combo cards.

weyland

Beware of posted bounty! Other cards won't be problem! Have plascrete in early game is crucial.

NEH

make sure you have hostage in your starting hand, pull your the source! Or fast advance leads to your lose.

MN

siphon approach. Don't be afraid of midseason since you seldom steal agendas.

ETF

make sure you tear down the melange ASAP
Or this ID will be too rich to siphon.

RP

Sundew is a nightmare! Don't hesitate to tear down sundew! Even if you will slowed down.

Leave your comment let me know your idea!

name: Tenma event organizer v2
description:
Pretty simple deck strategy. Focus on the central servers, digging deep when you can with Indexing, The Maker's Eye and Legwork using Account Siphons as many times as possible. Its a tag-me style deck with no resources other than Same Old Thing.

Crypsis is there to help hit remotes, hopefully after you have built up your Datasucker's and money from Account Siphon.

I've had some luck digging out all my event based economy, then popping Levy AR Access to do it all over again.

name: NEH : Tournament Winner (Paris - 12 Oct. 2014)
description:
Nothing really outstanding or specific in this deck, it's your standard Fast Advance NBN deck.

  • I went with 2 Mental Health Clinic, instead of the usual out of faction ICE selection (Lotus Field, Eli ...). It was a test, but I'm quite happy with it. This deck doesn't thrive in late game in any case, and MHC can make a huge difference in early/mid-game compared to PAD Campaign

  • Only 2 Fast Tracks : there should be 3; cut out that Closed Account to include a 3rd copy. This card win games, seriously, I don't know why I was only packing 2.

name: Noise : Tournament Winner (Paris - 12 Oct. 2014)
description:
Nothing really outstanding or really original in this deck. Most Noise decks revolve around the same key cards (about 30/35) whic don't leave much room for creativity in any case.

A few highlights on cards that may be debatable :

  • Sahasrara : One of the best economy cards available for Noise, as an early Sahasrara can easily grant you a net 15 to 20 gold in the whole game. It's quite useless in late game, which means you need to play 3 to hope and get one early.

  • Unique key cards are in 3 copies ( Aesop's Pawnshop, Grimoire, Wyldside). I have seen a few lists that run only 2, but I prefer the stability of having 3. The sooner you get them, the better your economy and your deck will run.

  • Djinn : Djinn gives to powerful effects to Noise decks : virus tutor and additional MU. Like Sahasrara, you need to see one early (meaning, before you start installing all your datasuckers, imps and Mediums). Searching for a Cache may be a winning move too.

  • Corroders : Many versions don't include Corroder, but it's so cost effective and barriers are so played it deserves its spot.

  • 1 Nerve Agent : it's useful against a limited number of decks, but when it does, it's often a game winner. With Datapack 4 available soon, and Cerebral Imaging getting some support, its usefulness can only grow.

name: SANIC (Winner, GNK Card Kingdom Seattle, 09/28/2014)
description:
This deck took 1st place in a GNK tournament on September 28, 2014, and I've already made the lists public, so I might as well publish them here, too. There were 24 players, and it was 5 rounds of Swiss with no cut. I've been continuing to play this deck since then and I don't think it's lost a game since the tournament.

This deck won 4/5 games, where the loss was to NEH Astrobiotics, and I probably could have mulliganed better. An earlier version of this deck had some decent luck against the archetype in the past; you just gotta go fast.

Mostly standard criminal fare; run early, run often, only stop when the ice tells you to. Tenma's been fairly underrepresented as far as blue decks go, but he's still really solid. PPVP really helps both the run and non-run events shine. It's gone to the point where I don't even include plascrete because it does a really good job keeping up with a scorch deck's economy. Sec Testing helps that a lot, too, forcing the corp to defend all of their servers if they don't want me to get a lot of benefits out of only one click.

I'd like to accelerate the card draw a bit if I can; sometimes the one card in my deck that I need (usually Special Order) is too slow in arriving. I've tried John Masanori but the downside was really hurting me in some games, and that's no good. Express Delivery would be nice if I decide to cut something for it.

Credit goes to my friend Kyle for indirectly inspiring me to build this deck and helping me make some last minute changes, and to Simon Bradford (choux) for his 2nd place Canadian Nationals PPVP Tenma deck that helped a lot with some of the initial refinement.

name: Meteor Storm! (Winner, GNK Card Kingdom Seattle, 09/28/2014)
description:
This deck took 1st place in a GNK tournament on September 28, 2014, and I've already made the lists public, so I might as well publish them here, too. There were 24 entrants with 5 rounds of Swiss and no cut. It went 4/5 on the day, where its only loss was to a Noise, and I made a mistake on turn 1 by intending to play a hedge fund and pulling out scorch by accident. :P

This deck is an extension of some 3-popup decks that I've made in the past and have had surprising results, including a 5th place at a Plugged In tournament. NEH makes this deck a lot better by emphasizing its strengths (now you draw lots of cards while making all of these remotes), shoring up some weaknesses (extra influence to spend on snares to help with huge central assaults), and just making room for a few more useful cards. I've broken from the balls to the wall 3 popup tradition and added a bit more ice; just enough to make it taxing for the runner while not putting too much of a dent in NBN's coffers.

The plan is still the same. Overwhelm the runner with remotes. If they go for the remotes midseason them when they steal an agenda. If they don't get the train rolling. You also have the advantage of initially looking like the dominant archetype in the current meta, and runners might get a little bit too aggressive and get burned as a result.

The deck can be surprisingly versatile; out of the four wins I had, one was a 7-point psychobeale, one was an astrotrain into breaking news, one was a triple scorch through plascrete, and one was a poor guy who hit a snare with two cards.

The deck's biggest weaknesses are probably anarch in general (Noise, Whizzard to a lesser degree, Imp, Keyhole), and potentially repeated siphon spam, but it's not a losing battle; you just have to get a bit luckier in those matchups. There's a lot of targets anarchs have to trash to completely ruin you; if they hit a scorch, you can still fast advance, and if they get agendas, they might not have enough money to deal with the punishment that might follow.

name: Junk Yard Dogs
description: I wanted to bounce the Cerberus, only used two, and built from there

name: Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory
description:
This was a deck that I threw together for laughs that ended up working reasonably well.

At its core, it's a reasonably standard stealth deck. Why Chaos Theory: Wünderkind? A small deck size helps set up stealth combos, and her extra MU means an extra cloak, which really helps.

The only real twist here is Oracle May and Motivation. Hear me out. 40 cards means that it's easier to set up combos. A stealth deck does a lot of digging for cards anyway.

May provides incredible economy, freeing up MUs that would usually go to Magnum Opus. These MUs mean more Cloaks.

name: W/R HellSinki City Grid VI - Helsinki, Finland
description:
Players: 12

Winner: Lauri "Ahein" Lauma

name: W/C HellSinki City Grid VI - Helsinki, Finland
description:
Players: 12

Winner: Lauri "Ahein" Lauma

name: Power Overwhelming
description:
What does any corporation really care about at the end of the day? Money. We all know the Weyland Corporation will do about anything for profits. From creating environmental hazards to blowing up buildings and the new branch of Weyland, Blue Sun, is running a monopoly on energy provision.

This deck follows true Weyland principal; making the big bucks. The idea is simple. Bad publicity? Who cares what the public thinks - profits are what matter. And publicity is good publicity, right? RIGHT?

With the credit gain this deck offers, there are two options. Scoring out behind a strong remote, or Midseasons/Scorch. Ireress provides the answer to all the BP. The only thing that messes with it is of course Yog. This is were Wendigo comes in - being outside of Yog range. Information Overload works beautifully with Midseasons. When successful, it can remove some key components in the runners rig (maybe even a Plascrete or two).

name: W/R Grand Con - Michigan, US
description:
Players: 12

Winner: Aaron Smith

name: Le Professor
description: The point of the deck is to have as many tools in your pocket as you can and only pull them out when you need them. Many of the programs are support programs that are effective but not necessary. You have all the answers to the questions, you just have to wait for the Corp to ask them. ;)

name: ModernSuperism
description: My shot at a Building a Better World deck. Using a lot of what I remember from playing the Supermodernism v2 deck in this construction.

name: Mare Amazonia Engine
description:
Play games with Rezing and then returning cards to HQ.

Adonis Campaign is an economic engine. Install it on an empty remote. If it survives, rez it at the end of the runner's turn, gain $3, then return it to hand to recoup the rez cost.

Amazon Industrial Zone and mid-cost ice is an economic engine. Put it on a low-value remote, pop the ice (or AIZ) off every turn, reinstall & rerez it at a discount. Efficiency of $3/click.

The Root can be rezzed in the opponents turn, used to chain rez Amazon Industrial Zone, Eve Campaign, etcetera, then it can be immediately returned to hand at a savings of $3/click. This also works rezzing ice if they're running on their last click, or if they don't have $4 handy.

Curtain Wall can be rezzed with Oversight AI, then returned to hand for $14, then reinstalled "for real". Once you have $20+, Curtain Wall is obnoxiously mobile.

Wendigo sets up Archer ambushes. Disable their killer and burn their rig down.

name: Bring the No-ICE
description:
Goal of the deck is to win via net damage, but if you bluff your way through, you could win via Agenda points too. I try to leave agendas that have been completely advanced on the table, and score them when I want to damage the runner.

The deck doesn't really care what how much Bad Publicity it racks up, if I can score a Profiteering early enough, it'll give me the credits I need to pay for most of my traps.

After lots of playthroughs, I've found the best way to play is to drop as many servers as I can, and equally advance all of them. Putting too many on any card in particular is no good.

Shocks/Shi-Kyu are meant to go into Archives, Cyberdex helps with Imps or Chakanas.

name: First deck
description: Not played First try.... Advice are welcome

name: The Purple Punisher
description:
This deck started as a way to try to make use of Midway Station Grid, because I think it has some real taxing potential in the right deck, and HB have a good amount of ice with multi routines. Custom biotics seemed to make sense as it gives me the influence to include MSG and Archers, which could make a very tough to crack remote.

This has now become an all round punishing glacier style deck, with a good amount of flatline potential. I've gone for all 5/3 agendas since that ties in with the glacier idea. Since I'll have quite a few IAA turns, Cerebral Overwriter and GRNDL made sense to try to catch the runner out, drain some credits etc.

Enhanced Login Protocol and Strongbox I'm hoping will mitigate the click through issues with bioroid ice. In thoery, ELP, Strongbox and and Eli or Victor is enough to keep a breakerless runner out for the early agenda score, unless they have a run event.

The ice is generally designed to cause a headache. Namely, brain damage. If you can get the runner to 3 brain damage through ice and/or cerebrals, then one punitive counterstrike is all it takes. Otherwise, if you've got a good credit advantage, 2 should do the job.

All thoughts, comments & critiques welcome.

name: The Power Of The Future - Today!
description:
This is my Blue Sun Deck. I have been testing it for about a week, and it is undefeated in-person and 14-2 online. Some of that is due to people not being familiar in how to play against it, but I also believe this is going to become one of the strongest identities when Weyland gets even more tricks in the near future.

Playstyle

This deck is all about keeping yourself pretty rich. It has the typical SEA Source / Scorched Earth combo, as well as some pretty big ice that you can rez over time because you never "lose" money in this deck. You always have your cred pool + whatever your highest rez-cost ice is for your trace, so flatline has been the primary win condition so far.

This deck is all about hitting scoring windows. You want to get one over-advanced Project Atlas as soon as you can to threaten flatline as well as stop Indexings and assure that you always have some econ.

Agendas

Somewhat familiar agenda spread here. Project Atlas can find you the game winning Hostile Takeover often. Priority Requisition gives you free money. I'm still playing around with having both the fragments. Eden Fragment stays for sure, as you will be installing ice a lot in this deck. Hades Fragment is more of an anti-Noise / Power Shutdown combo agenda that may or may not be replaced.

Econ

These are pretty straightforward. Unless you're getting hit by some serious Account Siphon pressure, you're never that far from Restructure. One of your best moves early for econ is to create a new server with Curtain Wall and use Oversight AI. It will take the runner 11 credits to break it if they want to stop you, but if they do not next turn it will net you 13 credits for a total of two clicks (three if you want to install it again). The Root is Weyland's Sundew in this deck, protect it moderately well early on and then when it is done serving its purpose bounce it back for some more cash.

Ice

I wanted a good spread of cheap, early game ice and late-game glacier ice. The best ice you can have in your starting hand is Caduceus. If you get the first trace off, Caduceus is free to rez, then you can bounce it back later essentially turning into a better Beanstalk Royalties. Tollbooth is a monster because you zap the runner for 3, then pull it back into your hand and put it somewhere else to do the same. You have Taurus for Plascrete / other hardware destruction, and my personal favorite splash - Flare. Hive is another piece of strong early-game ice that you can just bounce back for a free Restructure once you have scored some points.

Odds and Ends

I've included Elizabeth Mills for some more anti-Nosie/Personal Workshop shenanigans as well as bad publicity removal. Power Shutdown is a great card to help create scoring windows, but I am considering changing it out. Also watch out for Emergency Shutdown. That card can hurt you. Bad.

name: Toying around w/ The Foundry
Strongerest Together
description: Lure the runner into delaying their breakers with clickable ICE until you're ready, then lock them out with Tollbooths and additional bioroids and start churning out agendas. Adonis, Melange, and Heinlein all force the runner to waste their clicks and money to keep you from getting ahead. Punitive is a backup win condition in case they get lucky with agenda pulls. (no one seems to bother with Plascretes against HB:ST!)

name: Silent Kate
Replicating Babies U&O
description:
My planned updates to my long-running Replicating Perfection deck. Been having more and more trouble with Parasite recursion since Anarch has been more and more prevalent in my meta, so I added Lotus Fields, and diversified my ice to get rid of a lot of 4-strength pieces, including my beloved RSVPs :(.

Fortunately, Reversed Accounts is super fun, since I can usually bluff it as a Fetal or NAPD, which the runner is happy to leave alone early in the game.

name: Da Prof
description: Do you have any suggetions how to improve the deck?

name: Wuncler's Conspiracy (Gangster Shit)
description: Janky fun with Ash, Crisium, and Off the Grid. Crisium really kills multi-access, AS, Vamp, etc.

name: Stealth Starter Kit
description:
This is my most recent runner deck, I think I am in love. It is currently 28/4 and its the stealth deck I have always wanted.

Stealth is powerful but can set up kind of slow, so I thought to myself, "how do I fix that?" I use a runner that can survive the early game with one breaker out, Kit.

kits ability plus a refractor and a source of stealth the starting hand means i can run anywhere turn one and force the corp to spend a lot more than me. I can maintain pressure as i get set up with professional contacts and build kati money.

Once I am full rig there is no safe place for agendas and I can hard RD lock or dive hq or a remote.

let me know what you think.

You can find my blog here

http://self-modifyingcode.com/

name: Be Quick Or Be Dead
description: Again using Bullfrog for the kill. But instead of Port Anson Grid, use the counter from Labyrinthine Servers. Try to score it early. If the traps fail, Trick the counters into an Caprice Nisei + agenda server next turn. Play bold and fast.

name: code gate city (stealth edition)
description: I want to think i know what i'm doing here, but i just don't know, input is wanted here please

name: Painting on a Dinosaur
description:
The strategy is to play the early game running as much as possible. Yog.0 ASAP, don't worry about Dinosaurus. There's recursion a pleanty so if they blow up your Yog with a Grim, Archer or Rototurret, don't worry; it'll be back.

The Dino will come soon, which will increase your pressure. Depending on how well you're being kept out, either add breakers (or Femme Fatale) or start putting on pressure with Nerve Agent or Imp (preferably Imp) on HQ and R&D Interface or The Maker's Eye on R&D. Paintbrush can come out near the late game when servers start to become taxing to turn some inner sentries (I'm looking at you, Komainu) into easily Yoggable jokes.

name: Leela - Aggressive Denial
Ken Ten's Omnitricks
Leela - Resource Control
Noise Cache
description:
My take on the Noise cache archetype.

Not just a straight mill, access servers with Darwin/Overmind/D4vid. Install extra copies of hardware with inside man, and sell to Aesop. Other virrii are for support.

name: PE Hotness
description: My take on maximizing PE's ability to punish the runner. Still subject to playtesting / Tweaking.
